Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is to investigate new methods to direct colloidal assembly for robust, controllable and scalable manufacturing of various structured functional nanomaterials. Specifically, dielectrophoresis (DEP)-directed assembly of nanocolloidal building blocks under ac-electric fields of varied frequency and voltage will be explored to produce hierarchical nanostructured materials and devices, aiming to a development of prototypical nanoscale manufacturing schemes. Owing to the currently inadequate understanding of nanocolloidal DEP behaviors, the fundamental of nanoscale ac-polarization and DEP-induced dynamics will be examined and understood with latex nanoparticles of varied size from 10-100 nm in aqueous media as a model system. To enable in-situ and sensitive experimental characterization, ultrafast singe-particle fluorescence spectroscopy technique integrated with microfluidic devices will be employed to examine the scaling of nanocolloidal DEP characteristics with colloidal size and conductance and medium conductivity, which can be used to effectively scale the nanomanufacturing of hierarchical nanocolloidal assembly with varied colloidal dimension and suspension condition.

If successful, directed assembly of various nanocolloidal building blocks under ac-electric fields can be developed as a practical and versatile method to achieve robust, controllable and scalable nanofabrication and nanomanufacturing of structured functional nanomaterials, composites and coatings. When combined with current microfluidics technology, the DEP-based approach for nanocolloidal manipulation and assembly can be transformative and broadly applied to emerging bio/nanotechnology, such as the synthesis of novel photonic materials and porous separation membranes, rapid fabrication of biosensors and protein crystal arrays. Graduate and undergraduate student participants, as well as underrepresented minorities including female students in engineering majors, will be trained with new and advanced nanomaterials synthesis and characterization techniques through classroom instruction and laboratory research. This project also seeks to establish a strong coalition with relevant industrial corporations to help students, scientists and engineers work well together.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanocolloidal assembly has been well recognized as one of the major nanomanufacturing tools for emerging nanotechnology. The building blocks used for nanomanufacturing of hierarchical nanomaterials include colloidal nanoparticles, macromolecules and supramolecular assemblies. Assembly of these building blocks into useful devices requires the ability to manipulate and place them with nanometer scale precision, and to do so repeatedly and expeditiously from thousands or billions of times per device. One of critical challenges is to develop robust, rapid, controllable, and scalable methods for assembling functional nanocolloidal “building blocks” into hierarchically structured materials and devices. Common solution self-assembly apparently undergoes a very slow process, and the assembled structures that are determined by the thermodynamic and hydrodynamic properties of building blocks are least tunable. Dielectrophoresis directed nanocolloidal assembly under the application of non-uniform ac-electric fields to overcome thermodynamic and hydrodynamic forces becomes a promising and powerful approach in order to assemble large numbers of various organic and inorganic nanoparticles with high speed, selectivity and precision.

In this project, we set out to control and understand the nanoscale ac-electric polarization of multicomponent nanocolloidal mixture in aqueous media and develop a rapid and scalable dielectrophoresis assisted nanomanufacturing of hierarchically structured nanocolloidal assemblies. In particular, we integrated ultrafast singe-molecule fluorescence spectroscopy with microelectrode-embedded microfluidic devices to in-situ control and characterize the dielectrophoretic dynamics and assembly of binary nanocolloidal mixtures of distinct chemistry, architecture, and dimension. Our results determined optimal ac-field parameters such as ac-frequency and microelectrode configuration to effectively modulate the conformation and local counterion gradient of charged polymers and biopolymers to facilitate their supramolecular assembly with nanoparticles. From the molecular level experimental characterization, we established a scaling of nanocolloidal dielectrophoresis characteristics with nanocolloidal size and conductance and medium conductivity, which can be used to scale-up nanomanufacturing of hierarchical nanocolloidal assembly.

The project was instrumental in training one postdoctoral researcher, two PhD students, and five undergraduate students (two of whom are female students) over the entire grant period.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2016
Modified by: Yingxi (Elaine) Zhu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Nanocolloidal assembly has been well recognized as one of the major nanomanufacturing tools for emerging nanotechnology. The building blocks used for nanomanufacturing of hierarchical nanomaterials include colloidal nanoparticles, macromolecules and supramolecular assemblies. Assembly of these building blocks into useful devices requires the ability to manipulate and place them with nanometer scale precision, and to do so repeatedly and expeditiously from thousands or billions of times per device. Common solution self-assembly apparently undergoes a very slow process, and the assembled structures that are determined by the thermodynamic and hydrodynamic properties of building blocks are least tunable. Dielectrophoresis directed nanocolloidal assembly under the application of non-uniform ac-electric fields to overcome thermodynamic and hydrodynamic forces becomes a promising and powerful approach in order to assemble large numbers of various organic and inorganic nanoparticles with high speed, selectivity and precision. The project was instrumental in training one postdoctoral researcher, two PhD students, and five undergraduate students (two of whom are female students) over the entire grant period.
